content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: good, easy to solve, does something new

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Seems a bit easy for Fastest, but should be fun for Shortest and Reverse!
(Problem description + test cases seemed ok)

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I like easy problems to have short, concise definitions without any ceremony, and this fits well.

Goal
* Please change `N` to [[N]].

* Please format 0 as a {{constant}}.

* Please remove the examples. An example has been automatically shown in the Example section.

Input
* Line 2: Please change "int" to "integer".

Output
* Please change **0** to {{0}}.

Constraints
* Please change 10,000 to 10 as N is never greater than 10 in all the existing cases.

* Please change 1,000,000 to 1000 for a similar reason.

Cases
* Each test and its validator should cover the same scenario with similar input (in terms of magnitude) and different output wherever possible. Hence please make the changes as follows:

  • Test 1 (used in the Example section): Please include another odd integer in the input to better illustrate the task.
  
  • Validator 1: Please include 2 odd integers in the input so that it's similar to Test 1.
  
  • Validator 2: Please change to input to consist of odd integers only, and in ascending order. The output should not be 9.
  
* Please add a new pair of cases for each of the following scenarios:

  • The input consists of only a single odd integer greater than 100.

  • The input consists of a mix of random odd and even integers between 102 and 999, and the first integer is the expected output.
  
  • The input consists of 7 or more even integers of 2 to 3 digits.
  
  • The input consists of 7 or more odd integers of 1 to 3 digits in completely random order.

Thanks.
Thanks for the comments. I addressed them all.

Thank you for the quick response! If you don't mind, would you please add one new pair of cases where the input consists of even integers only except one? That scenario is like your original Test 1, but since that's been changed for a better example to show in the Example section, that scenario is missing now.

Thanks again.
Thank you for your help, I added the example.
